ground_truth: As Alice nervously drives, she shakes her head: no. Alice nods; if not quite relieved, at least grateful for Joe. But they all stare off for a long beat. CRANE DOWN as the Buick pulls up. The dusty boys pile out. They all kind of look at each other. Charles, who looks at Joe for a beat, holds up his defunct camera on the tripod. Joe nods. Alice finds something on the passenger seat and holds it out. Joe goes to the window. Alice holds it out: THE CUBE. He takes it with. It all continues as Joe has entered from the front door. Joe is moving toward the living room, where Charles sits on the sofa, eyes glued to the TV, a train crash being reported on the local news; helicopter shot of the wreck. Both stare at the train crash, stunned. And we push in on Charles, going from depressed and lost to. Joe and Charles ride their bikes into town, across a bridge, the massive steel mill in the background. Tilt down from the town's water tower -- Joe and Charles ride their bikes underneath it, crossing Main Street -- two large military trucks drive past, we may note the airman in the passenger seat scans the area with a handheld device. As Charles opens the camera, pulls out the film. Charles reacts; he's never smoked anything. Lower-lower-middle class house, set against woods. Joe with Alice at her front door. She seems unnerved. Joe watches Louis get out of the car -- the man who got arrested at his mother's wake -- carrying a small grocery bag. He sees Joe and darkens as he approaches. Joe steps back as Louis arrives; Louis seems to hate Joe, but at the same time, can barely look at him. Louis goes back inside. Alice follows, turns to Joe. Then, quietly, conflicted. She closes the door. Alone, despite it all, Joe is happy. Off his smile, we hear loud pops: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM. Martin -- as Detective Hathaway -- fires a gun -- shooting Cary, dressed in a dirty suit, as a man turning into a zombie -- his eyes wide and glossy white -- and as he is hit by the bullets, he slams his hand onto his chest -- blood bursts all over him, and he falls painfully to the ground. We then find Charles, behind his camera, yelling out. Wide shot, rising past six bicycles, thrown to the ground in a typical kid jumble. Charles, Joe, and Preston, with Joe's dad's Kodak camera on a tripod, have been filming, their gear scattered. Keep moving over them, to Martin and Alice, who were on camera. Beyond them, in the valley, the train crash seems to go forever.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: As Alice nervously drives, she shakes her head no, then nods—grateful for Joe, if not relieved. They all stare off in silence. CRANE DOWN as the Buick arrives and the dusty boys get out, exchanging glances. Charles looks at Joe, holding up his broken camera; Joe nods. Alice finds something on the seat—THE CUBE—and hands it to Joe through the window. Joe, now inside, heads to the living room, where Charles watches news footage of a train crash. Both are stunned. We push in on Charles, shifting from depressed to focused. Joe and Charles ride bikes into town, across a bridge with the steel mill in the background. TILT DOWN from the water tower—military trucks pass as an airman scans the area with a device. Charles opens the camera, pulling out the film, reacting—he's never smoked. A lower-middle-class home near woods: Joe is with Alice at her door. She's uneasy. Joe watches Louis, who was arrested at his mom’s wake, exit a car with a grocery bag. Louis glares, avoids eye contact, then goes inside. Alice follows, conflicted, turns to Joe, then quietly closes the door. Despite everything, Joe smiles. BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM!—Martin, as Detective Hathaway, shoots Cary, in a dirty suit, acting as a zombie. Blood bursts as Cary collapses. Charles, behind his camera, yells. Wide shot past six tossed bikes—Charles, Joe, and Preston film using Joe's dad's Kodak camera. Their gear is scattered. We move over them to Martin and Alice, who were acting. In the valley beyond, the train crash stretches endlessly.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: As Alice drives nervously, she shakes her head no, then nods—grateful for Joe. They all stare off. CRANE DOWN as the Buick arrives. The dusty boys exit, exchange looks. Charles eyes Joe, lifts his broken tripod-mounted camera. Joe nods. Alice finds something in the seat—THE CUBE—and gives it to Joe at the window. Joe enters the front door, heads to the living room where Charles watches a news report of a train crash—helicopter footage. Both stare, stunned. Push in on Charles, his expression shifting. Joe and Charles bike into town, past a steel mill, under the water tower. On Main Street, military trucks pass, an airman scans with a handheld device. Charles opens the camera, pulls the film—he’s never smoked. Lower-class house near woods. Joe visits Alice. She’s uneasy. Joe watches Louis, who was arrested at his mom’s wake, exit a car with a grocery bag. Louis sees Joe, scowls, and walks past. Joe steps back. Louis enters. Alice follows, turns to Joe, then conflicted, closes the door. Joe smiles—happy despite it all. BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM! Martin, as Detective Hathaway, shoots Cary, dressed like a zombifying man—white eyes, blood bursts as he collapses. Charles films, yelling. Wide shot: six bikes lie in a heap. Charles, Joe, Preston film with Joe’s dad’s Kodak. Gear scattered. Pan over to Martin and Alice on camera. In the distance, the train wreck stretches endlessly.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: As Alice drives with a palpable sense of nervousness, she shakes her head in a gesture that clearly signifies a firm "no." Despite her anxiety, Alice nods; she may not be entirely relieved, but she is at least grateful for Joe's presence. However, they all find themselves staring off into the distance for an extended moment. The camera CRANES DOWN as the Buick slowly pulls up to a stop. The dusty boys, looking somewhat disheveled, pile out of the vehicle. They all exchange glances, each one trying to read the others' thoughts. Charles, who takes a moment to look at Joe, holds up his broken camera, which is still mounted on the tripod. Joe acknowledges him with a nod. Meanwhile, Alice discovers something on the passenger seat and extends it toward Joe. He approaches the window, and Alice hands it to him: it is THE CUBE. He takes it with him as the scene continues, with Joe entering through the front door. Joe makes his way toward the living room, where Charles is seated on the sofa, his eyes fixed on the television screen, which is broadcasting a report about a train crash on the local news; the footage includes a helicopter shot of the wreckage. Both Joe and Charles stare at the train crash, visibly stunned by the sight. The camera pushes in on Charles, capturing his transition from a state of depression and confusion to something else. Joe and Charles then ride their bikes into town, crossing a bridge with the massive steel mill looming in the background. The camera tilts down from the town's water tower as Joe and Charles ride their bikes underneath it, crossing Main Street. Two large military trucks drive past them, and we may notice the airman in the passenger seat scanning the area with a handheld device. As Charles opens the camera and pulls out the film, he reacts with surprise; it's clear he's never smoked anything before. The scene shifts to a lower-lower-middle-class house, set against a backdrop of woods. Joe stands with Alice at her front door. She appears unnerved, her demeanor tense. Joe watches as Louis gets out of the car -- the same man who was arrested at his mother's wake -- carrying a small grocery bag. Louis sees Joe and his expression darkens as he approaches. Joe instinctively steps back as Louis arrives; it's evident that Louis harbors a strong dislike for Joe, yet he can barely bring himself to look at him. Louis goes back inside, and Alice follows, turning to Joe with a quiet, conflicted expression. She closes the door, leaving Joe alone. Despite everything, Joe feels a sense of happiness. Off his smile, we hear loud, startling pops: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM. Martin, portraying Detective Hathaway, fires a gun, shooting Cary, who is dressed in a dirty suit and playing the role of a man transforming into a zombie -- his eyes wide and glossy white. As the bullets hit him, Cary dramatically slams his hand onto his chest, causing blood to burst all over him, and he falls painfully to the ground. We then find Charles behind his camera, yelling out directions. The camera captures a wide shot, rising past six bicycles that have been carelessly thrown to the ground in a typical kid jumble. Charles, Joe, and Preston, with Joe's dad's Kodak camera on a tripod, have been filming, their gear scattered around them. The camera continues to move over them, revealing Martin and Alice, who were on camera. Beyond them, in the valley, the train crash seems to stretch on endlessly.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
As Alice navigates the road, her driving tinged with a palpable sense of nervousness, she shakes her head in a deliberate gesture that unmistakably signifies a firm "no." Despite her evident anxiety, there is a moment when Alice nods; she may not be entirely relieved of her apprehension, but there is a sense that she is at least grateful for having Joe by her side. However, in that shared moment, they all find themselves staring off into the distance, their gazes held for what feels like an extended period. The camera begins to CRANE DOWN as the Buick slowly and deliberately pulls up to a stop. Emerging from the vehicle, the dusty boys, looking rather disheveled, pile out in a somewhat haphazard manner. They exchange glances, with each one attempting to decipher the others' thoughts. Charles, taking a moment to look at Joe, holds up his broken camera, which remains mounted on the tripod. Joe acknowledges Charles with a nod of understanding. Meanwhile, Alice discovers an object on the passenger seat and extends it toward Joe. He approaches the window, and with a careful movement, Alice hands it to him: it is THE CUBE. Taking it with him, the scene continues as Joe enters through the front door, making his way toward the living room. There, Charles is seated on the sofa, his eyes fixed on the television screen, which is broadcasting a report about a train crash on the local news; the footage features an aerial helicopter shot of the wreckage strewn across the landscape. Both Joe and Charles stand there, staring at the train crash, visibly stunned and taken aback by the dramatic sight before them. The camera pushes in on Charles, capturing his transition from a state of depression and bewilderment to something else entirely. 

Joe and Charles then ride their bikes into town, crossing a bridge with the massive and imposing steel mill looming in the background like a silent sentinel. The camera tilts down from the town's water tower as Joe and Charles pedal their bikes underneath it, making their way across Main Street. As they do so, two large military trucks drive past them, and we may observe the airman in the passenger seat scanning the area with a handheld device. In a moment of surprise, Charles opens the camera and pulls out the film; it becomes clear that he has never smoked anything before, reacting with visible surprise.

The scene then transitions to a lower-lower-middle-class house, set against a picturesque backdrop of woods. Joe stands with Alice at her front door. She appears unnerved, her demeanor tense and anxious. Joe watches as Louis gets out of the car – the very same man who had been arrested at his mother's wake – carrying a small grocery bag. As Louis sees Joe, his expression darkens immediately, growing more serious as he approaches. Joe instinctively steps back as Louis arrives; it's evident that Louis harbors a strong dislike for Joe, yet he can barely bring himself to look directly at him. Louis retreats inside the house, and Alice follows, turning to Joe with a quiet and conflicted expression that speaks volumes. She closes the door, leaving Joe standing alone outside. Despite everything, an unexpected sense of happiness wells up within Joe. Off his smile, we hear loud, startling pops: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM. Martin, portraying Detective Hathaway, fires a gun, shooting Cary, who is dressed in a dirty suit and playing the role of a man transforming into a zombie, his eyes wide and glossy white. As the bullets hit him, Cary dramatically slams his hand onto his chest, causing blood to burst all over him, and he falls to the ground in a theatrical display. We then find Charles behind his camera, fervently yelling out directions. The camera captures a wide shot, rising past six bicycles that have been carelessly thrown to the ground in a typical kid jumble. Charles, Joe, and Preston, with Joe's dad's Kodak camera perched on a tripod, have been filming, their gear scattered around them like a nest of creativity. The camera continues to move over them, revealing Martin and Alice, who were participating in the scene on camera. Beyond them, in the valley, the train crash stretches on, seemingly endlessly, a testament to the chaos that unfolded.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Alice nervously grips the steering wheel, she drives with a tense expression, her head shaking slightly from side to side, indicating a silent "no" to herself. Despite her nerves, Alice manages a nod, acknowledging a sense of gratitude, if not complete relief, for Joe's presence. They all sit in silence, their gazes fixed in the distance, lost in thought for a long moment. The camera cranes down as the Buick slowly pulls up to a stop, and the dusty boys begin to clamber out of the vehicle, each one glancing around at the others with a mix of anticipation and uncertainty. Charles, standing apart, looks directly at Joe for a moment before raising his broken camera, still mounted on its tripod, as if to signal something unspoken. Joe responds with a nod of understanding. Meanwhile, Alice, seated in the passenger seat, spots something beside her and picks it up, extending her hand to offer it to Joe. He approaches the window, and Alice hands him the object: THE CUBE. Joe accepts it, and the scene transitions as he enters the house through the front door. Inside, Joe moves purposefully toward the living room, where he finds Charles seated on the sofa, his eyes glued to the television screen, which is broadcasting a report of a train crash, complete with a helicopter shot of the wreckage. Both boys stare at the screen, their expressions a mix of shock and disbelief. The camera pushes in on Charles, capturing his transition from a state of depression and confusion to something more resolved. The scene shifts as Joe and Charles ride their bikes into town, pedaling across a bridge with the imposing steel mill looming in the background. The camera tilts down from the town's water tower as Joe and Charles ride beneath it, crossing Main Street just as two large military trucks rumble past. An airman in the passenger seat of one truck scans the area with a handheld device, adding to the tension. As Charles opens his camera and extracts the film, he reacts with surprise, having never smoked anything before. The setting changes to a lower-lower-middle-class house nestled against the woods, where Joe stands with Alice at her front door. Alice appears unsettled, and Joe watches as Louis, the man who was arrested at his mother's wake, exits a car carrying a small grocery bag. Louis notices Joe and his expression darkens as he approaches. Joe instinctively steps back as Louis arrives, sensing the man's animosity, though Louis can barely bring himself to meet Joe's gaze. Louis retreats inside, and Alice follows, pausing to turn back to Joe with a conflicted look before quietly closing the door. Despite the tension, Joe feels a sense of happiness, a smile spreading across his face. Suddenly, the air is pierced by loud pops: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM. Martin, playing the role of Detective Hathaway, fires a gun, shooting at Cary, who is dressed in a dirty suit and portraying a man transforming into a zombie. Cary's eyes are wide and glossy white, and as the bullets hit him, he dramatically slams his hand onto his chest, causing fake blood to burst all over him as he collapses to the ground in a theatrical fall. The scene shifts to reveal Charles behind his camera, shouting directions with enthusiasm. The camera pulls back to a wide shot, revealing six bicycles haphazardly thrown to the ground in a typical kid jumble. Charles, Joe, and Preston are busy filming with Joe's dad's Kodak camera on a tripod, their equipment scattered around them. The camera continues to move over the scene, capturing Martin and Alice, who were in front of the camera, acting out their parts. Beyond them, in the valley, the aftermath of the train crash stretches endlessly, a haunting backdrop to their youthful filmmaking adventure.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Alice nervously drives, she shakes her head, indicating no, but then nods, feeling at least grateful for Joe's presence. They all share a long, contemplative moment. The Buick arrives, and the dusty boys exit, exchanging glances. Charles holds up his broken camera on a tripod, and Joe nods in acknowledgment. Alice finds something on the passenger seat and hands it to Joe through the window: THE CUBE. Joe takes it and enters the house, moving toward the living room where Charles is fixated on a TV report of a train crash. Both are stunned by the news. Joe and Charles then ride their bikes into town, passing under the water tower and crossing Main Street as military trucks drive by, with an airman scanning the area. Charles opens the camera and reacts, unfamiliar with smoking. At Alice's house, Joe watches Louis, who was arrested at his mother's wake, exit a car with a grocery bag. Louis darkens upon seeing Joe, who steps back as Louis approaches and then goes inside. Alice, appearing unnerved, follows Louis but turns to Joe, conflicted, before closing the door. Despite everything, Joe feels happy. Off his smile, loud pops are heard: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM. Martin, as Detective Hathaway, fires a gun at Cary, who is dressed as a zombie. Cary, with wide, glossy eyes, reacts to the bullets, blood bursting as he falls. Charles, behind his camera, yells out. A wide shot reveals six bicycles scattered on the ground. Charles, Joe, and Preston, with Joe's dad's Kodak camera on a tripod, have been filming, their gear scattered. The scene pans over to Martin and Alice, who were on camera, with the train crash extending endlessly in the valley beyond them.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: As Alice nervously drives through the quiet, tree-lined streets of their suburban neighborhood, she shakes her head: no. Alice nods; if not quite relieved, at least grateful for Joe, her steadfast friend since childhood. But they all stare off for a long beat, caught in a moment heavy with unspoken worries. CRANE DOWN as the vintage Buick, a classic car known for its robust design and popularity in the 1970s, pulls up. The dusty boys, who have been filming a homemade movie project all summer, pile out. They all kind of look at each other, sharing a moment of camaraderie. Charles, an aspiring young filmmaker, who looks at Joe for a beat, holds up his defunct camera on the tripod, a prized possession despite its state. Joe nods, understanding the significance of capturing each moment. Alice finds something on the passenger seat and holds it out. Joe goes to the window. Alice holds it out: THE CUBE, a mysterious object at the center of their sci-fi story. He takes it with purpose and curiosity. It all continues as Joe has entered from the front door of the house. Joe is moving toward the living room, where Charles sits on the sofa, eyes glued to the TV, as a train crash being reported on the local news unfolds; the footage is a helicopter shot of the wreck, reminiscent of the catastrophic train derailments that have occasionally shaken small communities. Both stare at the train crash, stunned by the scale of destruction. And we push in on Charles, going from depressed and lost to a sudden sense of determination. Joe and Charles ride their bikes into town, across a bridge that spans the wide river, the massive steel mill in the background, a testament to the town's industrial roots. Tilt down from the town's water tower -- a landmark often used in establishing shots to denote small-town America -- Joe and Charles ride their bikes underneath it, crossing Main Street -- two large military trucks drive past, we may note the airman in the passenger seat scans the area with a handheld device, a sign of heightened security measures. As Charles opens the camera, pulls out the film, he reacts; he's never smoked anything, and the scent of chemicals surprises him. Lower-lower-middle class house, set against woods, speaks of modest living conditions. Joe with Alice at her front door, where she seems unnerved by the recent events. Joe watches Louis get out of the car -- the man who got arrested at his mother's wake for reasons that cast a shadow over the family -- carrying a small grocery bag, a mundane task colored by tension. He sees Joe and darkens as he approaches, history and resentment clearly etched in his demeanor. Joe steps back as Louis arrives; Louis seems to hate Joe, but at the same time, can barely look at him, a conflict of emotions tied to past grievances. Louis goes back inside. Alice follows, turns to Joe. Then, quietly, conflicted in her loyalties. She closes the door with a sense of finality. Alone, despite it all, Joe is happy, finding solace in small victories. Off his smile, we hear loud pops: BAM! BAM! BAM! BAM. Martin -- as Detective Hathaway in their film project -- fires a gun loaded with blanks, adding realism to their scene -- shooting Cary, dressed in a dirty suit, as a man turning into a zombie -- his eyes wide and glossy white as per classic horror tropes -- and as he is hit by the bullets, he slams his hand onto his chest -- fake blood bursts all over him, a special effect crafted with care, and he falls painfully to the ground, committed to his role. We then find Charles, behind his camera, yelling out directions with passion. A wide shot captures the scene, rising past six bicycles, thrown to the ground in a typical kid jumble, symbolic of their carefree adventures. Charles, Joe, and Preston, with Joe's dad's Kodak camera on a tripod, have been filming, their gear scattered around in creative chaos. Keep moving over them, to Martin and Alice, who were on camera, embodying the characters they created. Beyond them, in the valley, the train crash seems to go on forever, a stark contrast to their imaginative escapades.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: While Beatrice anxiously dances, she nods her hand: yes. Beatrice shakes; if not quite anxious, at least regretful for Max. But they all sing out for a short melody. FLOAT UP as the Honda flies over. The shiny cats jump in. They all kind of laugh at each book. David, who laughs at Max for a melody, kicks up his broken microphone on the stand. Max shakes. Beatrice loses anything on the dashboard and drops it in. Max runs to the roof. Beatrice drops it in: THE SPHERE. He places it without. It all pauses as Max has exited from the back wall. Max is sprinting away from the dining room, where David dances on the floor, ears glued to the radio, a car chase being told on the national broadcast; drone view of the chaos. Both laugh at the car chase, amused. And we pull out from David, going from happy and found to. Max and David float their hovercrafts into the mountains, over a river, the massive glass tower in the foreground. Pan up from the village's lighthouse -- Max and David float their hovercrafts over it, climbing Elm Avenue -- two tiny bicycles pedal by, we may note the mailman on the skateboard watches the sky with a large telescope. As David shuts the microphone, shoves in the battery. David smiles; he's never cooked everything. Upper-upper-middle class cottage, laid inside deserts. Max with Beatrice at his back gate. He seems energized. Max hears Linda fly off the horse -- the woman who got promoted at her uncle's birthday -- holding a large toolbox. She hears Max and brightens as she leaves. Max jumps forward as Linda leaves; Linda seems to adore Max, but at the same time, can gently talk to her. Linda runs forward. Beatrice follows, jumps from Max. Then, loudly, joyous. She opens the wall. Together, because of it all, Max is sad. Off her frown, we see soft whispers: WHOOSH! WHOOSH! WHOOSH! WHOOSH. Nigel -- as Captain Taylor -- throws a spear -- stabbing Bonnie, dressed in a clean dress, as a woman turning into a ghost -- her hair short and shiny black -- and as she is touched by the spears, she lifts her foot onto her head -- water drips all inside her, and she rises softly to the ceiling. We then lose David, above his microphone, whispering in. Narrow view, dropping below three mopeds, lifted to the sky in a random pet stack. David, Max, and Felix, with Max's mom's Nikon microphone on a stand, have been drawing, their tools organized. Keep jumping under them, to Nigel and Beatrice, who were off-stage. Near them, in the mountain, the car chase seems to fly forever.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Alice drives nervously but is grateful for Joe's support. They arrive at a location where dusty boys exit a Buick, exchanging glances. Charles shows Joe his broken camera, and Alice hands Joe a cube from the seat. Inside, Charles and Joe are stunned by a train crash reported on TV. The boys ride their bikes into town, passing military trucks scanning the area. At Alice's house, Joe notices Louis, who seems hostile but avoids eye contact. Alice follows Louis inside and closes the door, leaving Joe alone but content. Meanwhile, the group films a zombie scene with Martin firing a fake gun at Cary. Charles, Joe, and Preston, using Joe’s dad’s Kodak camera, are engrossed in their production as the train crash looms in the valley.
